summary: Jane Hudson (Bette Davis) is an aging child star left to care for her wheelchair-bound sister Blanche (Joan Crawford), also a former child actress. Stuck living together in a mansion in old Hollywood, Blanche plots to get even with Jane for the car crash that left her crippled years earlier. But Jane is desperate to keep Blanche imprisoned as she plans a new rise to fame, and tries to hide Blanche's existence from doctors, visitors and neighbors while she devises a way to get rid of her sister.

reviews.content: Delightfully over-the-top psychological horror thriller gives Davis and Crawford the opportunity to go into full throttle competition with their performances; full of memorable moments - and some shock along the way.

(Spoilers) Ugly grand Guignol about a couple of hags trying to claw eachother to death.  Who wants to watch 2 hours of Bette torturing poor handicapped Joan; just to watch the even uglier revelation of the ending.  That revelation being that Joan started the whole thing in the first place by trying to kill Bette; and then handicapped herself by crashing her car.  Talk about ableism!  What a cruel film.  People talk about this being an ersatz sequel to Psycho in the whole Psychobiddy/Hagsploitation mini-cycle of the 60s.  And others refer to it as the prequel to Mommie Dearest.  And then there's all that backstage drama about the real-life rivalry between these two grand-dames; and how much of the onscreen fighting was real, etc.  And that all might make Baby Jane an interesting curio to some, but that's not enough to recommend it.  It's heavy handed humor and repetitively vicious plotline is unenjoyable.  Thumbs way down ladies!

If a notorious narrative reputation been perceived and reached in attachment to the title, then that's the mindset you should equip yourself as reminder on how disturbing this film has gone through, and you'll find out how it was brilliantly handled. An inhumane suspenseful thriller being defensively psychological in both meanings with frightening lengths between the oppressor's madness and the crippled weakness, progressing into a humane horror that creeps full blown like prolonging or slowly lingering the final "Sunset Boulevard" moment backed up by shared aesthetical preference. Even though unaware by the real-life rivalry between the two main stars [similarly] paired as sisters, both Davis and Crawford professionally grip their roles and stunningly embrace each psyche seemingly out of their comfort zones and mustered extra strength in performative handling. Davis especially establishes a genetic connection to "Gone Girl" with a demonic threat above Rosamund Pike's diabolicality, meaning any narrative consisting of a female serial killer would be placed third behind the two unwarranted disgrace. It's going to be a challenge to sit through the torturing madness as it adds a little extremity onto what Hitchcock had put together in his scenarios, but given the atmosphere, the ticking tactics and the commitments, it's fairly brilliant thanks to being elevated by enough inspired praiseworthy merits. (B+)
Bosley Crowther was hapless in his review, as usual.

Der Psychothriller wurde von Robert Aldrich effektvoll inszeniert. Das Drehbuch schrieb Lukas Heller. Die beiden Hauptdarsteller Bette Davis und Joan Crawford, gehen in ihren exaltierten Charakteren auf. Die Leitungen von Bette Davis und Joan Crawford sind nicht zu toppen.

Grotesque and fabulous in equal measure 
Davis & Crawford 2 of the all time greats showing why. 
Davis slides deeper & deeper the further the movie goes, uncomfortable to watch at times but unmissable ‚ù§Ô∏è

Well, I wouldn't call it horror but it was definitely way ahead of its time, that's for sure. There's a few moments in this movie, such as the rat scene in particular, where you think "wow, I wasn't expected them to do something like that!"

What Ever Happened to Baby Jane was a movie I once saw about 7 years ago, and in all honesty some of it traumatised me not just the purposefully grotesque make up but also the snarl-and-shriek chemistry between the two leads. Watching it again, the film maintains its chilling and shocking values, but there is also under the surface a sadness, compassion and campiness(in a good way) that I didn't notice as much previously.

What Ever Happened to Baby Jane is essentially a must see movie. The production values are superb, with beautiful yet atmospheric cinematography, well-tailored costumes, well-constructed/chosen sets/scenery and above all the grotesque yet brilliant make-up. The music never detracts from the atmosphere which is resolutely chilling albeit with moments of pathos as seen Davis' and Crawford's envy, the script shocks, amuses and delights and the story is well-paced and never less than interesting. Aldrich directs superbly, and while Victor Bueno is wonderful, it is the performances and hair-raising chemistry between the two leads that takes centre stage. Joan Crawford is superb, but Bette Davis has the meatier role as a very over-the-edge character and gives a portrayal that is both terrifying and heartbreaking.

Overall, a must see film especially for the leads. 10/10 Bethany Cox
I hate when a film insults my intelligence.  You want me to believe that a wad of paper will carry out the window more than her own voice?

Blanche NEVER calls the police, NEVER yells to her neighbor for help & waits until Jane is halfway through her road trip before even attempting to go downstairs to get to the telephone.  Jane doesn't even descend the stairs like a normal paralyzed person.  Instead of sitting down and going one step at a time while manually moving her feet, she decides to try and "stand" while supporting her weight while holding the handrail, inching her way down.  Gee, don't ALL elderly women do this???  I don't think so.  Elvira basically hands a hammer to Jane, then turns her back.  Would YOU?  Also, 2 cops eating lunch at the beach while a car is parked in the street, instead of off the road.  Someone needs to bring this to their attention before they do anything about it.  Okay, maybe that is realistic.  Completely absurd script.  The ONLY reason to watch this movie is to see one of Bette Davis' better performances.  A better choice would be Hush...Hush, Sweet Charlotte.

more than a lil campy at times, however the acting was great. To see the 2 of these tycoon actresses, get together and battle it on screen was amazing. I was particularly impressed by Davis' performance. The makeup was well done and I loved the setting of that old Hollywood mansion. Several iconic scenes, like the bird scene in the dish. It was sad, but also realistic in regard to child actors. The movie itself was often slowly paced, the extras in the movie were pretty bad (gee whiz robotic 50s kinds), script was meh, and I felt like it could've gone darker/more in depth with the characters with flashbacks or what not. Some of the shots of Davis were great, but overall cinematography was just ok. The twist ending was very ironic. Worth a watch if u r into classic films, Old Hollywood, or dark but campy films.
Excellent performance, I loved the ending.
Bette Davis at her best

A psychological drama full of jealousy, bitterness and spite, bolstered by 2 fantastic lead performances, What Ever Happened To Baby Jane marked a massive career resurgence for both its stars, and continues to be influential in the so-called ‚Äòpsycho-biddy' film genre. It keeps a steady pace for most of its runtime, before ramping things up significantly in the 3rd act. Some of the actions and even language seem very risqu√© for the time period, but I think that's one of the reasons that it was so successful. It feels like it wants to go all the way, not just giving us a few hints of what might transpire. Both Crawford and Davis throw themselves into their roles, though the latter is giving significantly more to do. It's not hard to believe that these 2 are sisters with a genuine animosity for one another, especially considering what the actresses thought of each other in real life. The ending is somewhat ambiguous, but it's clear to anyone watching what will happen to them. There's a few memorable side characters, including the house maid Elvira and piano player Edwin, but the reason the film has stayed in the public consciousness for as long as it has it entirely down to the 2 main characters, and how they go about tearing the other one down in their own way. A classic psychological thriller that will stay with you for a long time.
What a great movie about an old child star living in her dreams, but her older sister surpassed her years ago in acting, so Baby Jane gets revenge which will only be revealed in the ending!!!!
Saw when baby Blob.  Bette Davis at her best.

This movie moved rather slow, but I did appreciate that the set up, climax, and finale were well presented so you could get a good intuitive grasp of the motivation of the characters.  Nice twist as well.  I liked how the movie had an antique feel to it, everything from the automobiles to the genteel police.  My first foray into a black & white film on a high definition television.  A much improved experience than my previous experience watching black & white movies with my grandmother on her 32" standard definition tube.

The first 15 minutes and the last 15 minutes were interesting. In between was what felt like 50 hours of Bette Davis being mean beyond all reason and Joan Crawford being painfully dumb. I got so annoyed at the characters I simply lost interest in what happens to them.

Often you have to think of films in the context of their time, overlooking the features that have since been updated or refined. But What Ever Happened to Baby Jane? still feels like a genuinely creepy thriller, with a painfully simple premise (helpless characters that cannot provide for themselves being taken advantage of) driven home by a devilish, malicious performance from a high-powered lead; everything you liked about Misery is present in this Aldrich classic, with the exception that the film is set down the road rather than in the remote wilderness, and with a dash of Sunset Blvd on top of it.

What I can't understand is the belief that equal weight should be given to Crawford's performance compared to that of Bette Davis. Seeing Crawford spin a wheelchair frantically in a locked room does not seem nearly as daring or demanding as the neurotic, paranoid, and terrifying Jane Hudson, whose supreme selfishness and hate has calcified in the belief that her sister, rather than her own terrible nature, led to the demise of her career. She alternates between personalities in an attempt to retain some of the dignity from her past, offhandedly dismissing those who don't recognize her supposed beauty, meanwhile prancing around in a coat of makeup as thick as whitewash on a farmhouse in defiance of her inevitable aging. Jane is the star around which the film orbits, and to me it seems more reasonable to classify Crawford's turn as Blanche more in the context of a supporting role.

While it has nothing to do with Crawford herself, if there is a major problem with the film, it is the treatment of Blanche as a character. Despite being almost interred with her sister for decades by the time the meat of the film gets rolling, she still harbors some benefit of the doubt in her treatment of Jane, as if she genuinely believes there is some redeemable attribute to her character. Between this and Jane's immediately terrible behavior upon her introduction in her older state, there isn't much room for character development; when you already are witnessing an antagonist serve her victim her own pet parakeet as a meal, there isn't much more you need to do to convince the audience of her nature. Plus, there's plenty that could easily be edited out of this film, particularly toward the end - it's a half hour longer than necessary, and features an unnecessary bit of redemption at the end for a character that doesn't really need it. (4/5)
horror schmorror, this is only dramatic, but really cool too

Give me a break! The acting is superb, especially Davis and Crawford. But the story line is abysmal. I believed it when I was ten. But note to Blanche, try calling for help through the window! Of course that would have changed the running time from 133 minutes to about 15, but at least it would have been tethered to reality.
Well paced and interesting. Seems like Misery stole the premise a bit

Ok, now I see why this is such a legendary classic movie. Maybe it feels a bit lengthy, but still very captivating, as it's frequently pouring on more tension, causing frustration as you helplessly watch and‚Äîin turn‚Äîsympathize. Very well-done. There's an obvious comparison to make with 'Sunset Boulevard', but this stands alone as its own version of Hollywood-decay.
I wasn't a fan of horror movies... until I saw this movie. unexpected ending and Incredible from start to finish.
Bette Davis was robbed from getting the Best Actress Award for her role as Baby Jane!  Bette Davis was a true character actress, one of the greatest actors on screen!

Bette Davis and Joan Crawford give tour-de-force performances as the aging Hudson sisters in Robert Aldrich's Whatever Happened to Baby Jane?  Set primarily in a house shared by the sisters, the film steadily descends into a maelstrom of abuse, assault, madness, and murder as Baby Jane (Davis) torments her paraplegic sister Blanche (Crawford), who is confined to a room in the upstairs of their home.  The movie is gripping from start to finish, as long as one can overlook some of the glaring leaps in logic that exist throughout.  For example, if Blanche is able to open the window to throw a call for help letter to the driveway below, why not just scream for help?  In another scene, when she gets access to the phone, she calls her doctor instead of calling the police.  Despite this, Whatever Happened to Baby Jane? remains a wildly entertaining movie with great performances by both Davis and Crawford.
This is surprisingly still up to par with what we have today and is only enhanced by the infamous feud between its leads.
The acting is disgustingly superb! The cruelest character i have ever seen. Just WOW! 100%
I really liked this movie. It had creepy parts throughout and a mystery that lingered through the film about the relationship between the sisters.
Wow, with family like this who needs axe murderers?

This movie was so much fun and the chemistry, I guess we can call it, between Davis and Crawford made these two incredible performances possible. Some may label this film campy and I absolutely had a few unintended laughs but I loved the interplay between the two leads, especially knowing the history off camera, and found Bette Davis addictively magnetic. This was also an excellent choice, thematically speaking, to end my week long Bette Davis binge on.
*Binging Bette Davis #7
So much overacting it is hard to see anything else.

Mais o filme me prendeu

Bette Davis' acting was amazing, she certainly deserved an Oscar for it
Interesting for many reasons. I don‚Äôt think the movie ages that well, but you can tell the quality for time frame. What have been better in the theatre like most movies

On paper, this is dark suspense thriller with a plot not a million miles from Stephen King's Misery (a later creation). What elevates this film, however, is a spellbinding performance from Bette Davis. She is by turns creepy, sadistic, darkly comic, and tragic. The film is also surprisingly brutal for its time (for example, a kindly maid, concerned about the plight of Joan Crawford's character, is killed with a hammer). This is a must-see for anyone who likes dark psychological thrillers.

Few films attain the status of being a true camp classic and this is an essential film within the genre as two of the greatest divas of all time are united on screen with their real life rivalry bleeding over into the film. I have always been a fan of Joan Crawford as while her acting style could never be described as subtle she has a star quality that few performers possess and is an absolute revelation in Mildred Pierce (1945). I have never had the same affection for Davis but I can respect the fact that she is a great actress and it is terrifically entertaining to watch her camp it up in a deliciously villainous role. 57 years later this film still shocks, thrills and entertains as even those unfamiliar with the real life animosity between the lead actresses are wrapped up in the passions and tensions of the story.

Child star ‚ÄòBaby Jane' Hansen, Bette Davis, supports her family by playing a sweet innocent singer on stage while behind the scenes she is a spoilt, difficult child. Her sister Blanche, Joan Crawford, resents the attention she receives and years later as Hansen's career is on the decline and Blanche becomes a movie star the rivalry between the two intensifies. After a mysterious accident Blanche is left paraplegic with only Hansen to care for her, complicating matters is Hansen's alcoholism and declining mental state. After it is revealed that Blanche plans to sell their house Hansen begins starving Blanche as she has delusions of being a beloved child star again with the help of greedy pianist Edwin Flagg, Victor Buono. Blanche makes desperate attempts to escape but by the time the police have been alerted of the situation Hansen has whisked Blanche off to the beach where shocking revelations are made.

What elevates the film above it's imitators in the so-called ‚Äòhagsploitation' genre are the wholly committed performances of the leads who are aware of the fact that they are in a trashy film that intends to profit off of their real life personas and completely camp it up. Personally I prefer Crawford's more layered performance as the sympathetic victim who proves to be less innocent than she initially appears. She uses her eyes to great effect here as her expressions of intense fear as she tries her hardest to contact authorities before her sister arrives home convey a true terror. Davis is excellent in the more showy role as she poses in the mirror and flashes her teeth like the predatory figure we believe her to be. These same features make her haunting and rather sad when she pantomimes as the child performer she once was. Neither of the performances would work without the other as the two complement one another wonderfully and each get a chance to display their unique skill sets. This is what makes it so odd that Davis was the only to receive a Best Actress nomination as the two are equally brilliant and both should have been nominated despite how strong the 1962 Best Actress lineup was.

The real horror of the film is that so many sibling relationships teeter on the edge of this sort of mania as while the sisters hate one another they understand each other in a way that few others will. Davis' final lament, "You mean we could have been friends all this time?", is sad as many siblings will be able to relate to the feeling of regret over their mistreatment of their siblings. At heart the film is a story of two women who have been placed in opposition since childhood but who, at heart, want the same thing, to have successful careers in the entertainment industry. We end up feeling sorry for Baby Jane after hating her for so long as while she tortured her sister she has faced her own traumas and her actions were not necessarily driven by a desire to hurt her sister. Her sister represents everything that she can not attain and the alcohol and food restriction are a way to ignore her own insecurities.

Lovers of classic cinema and those who enjoy psychological thrillers will be instantly drawn to this film but it has a universal appeal in that deals more with human relationships than violence or gore.

This movie is a dark look into the aftermath of child stardom and the effect it can take on one's psyche.  Bette Davis steals the show with this chilling performance.  An absolute must see for any horror movie junkie.

Great performances, script. One scene in particular scared me as a kid, I won't give it away in case anyone out there hasn't seen it. Movies like this would confuse kids because the characters are acting proper and sweet up to a point but then the real adult traits of frustration and jealousy and murderous thoughts slip out --a rude awakening.  What ever happened to the old Hollywood? Where is the talent now?
Delightfully, smartly twisted. Bette Davis is phenomenal! Holy cow!!!

Interestingly complex, much more than you think it will be - being from the early 60's. One could be forgiven thinking this may be an Alfred Hitchcock film, but it is not. .  
The tension is pretty gripping, and Davis and Crawford really have lots of depth and layers to their characters.   I will give my nod to Bette Davis, for the amazing performance of a woman that tortured and damaged. I love Bette Davis' ability to allow herself to "not have to be pretty" and the roles where she was ugly inside and sometimes out.  
This movie is certainly one to keep you tense and alert, if not on the edge of your seat. Watching things unfold is the worst of it,, there is nothing too quick, and that's the problem.  It just keeps getting a bit worse and worse the further we go.  It's every bit as painful as a shock thriller, but artfully drawn out, and we are made to feel the pain and anxiety as we go along.  Joan Crawford, is excellent, for a role that keeps her in bed for the duration, and her acting compensates for any lack of movement, as her face is all the expression we need.  It's excruciating and manic at the same time.  Highly recommend.

it's amazing to see how easily influenced people are willing to be. this movie has more plot holes in it than a chicago street in the spring. blanche finally makes it to the phone after having been starved and terrorized, but she doesn't call the cops, she calls the psychiatrist...only to wait on hold. just dumb. elvira gets into the house to find blanche locked in. of course she didn't try to get help, she got a hammer and screwdriver. puh-leeze. all the while everybody knew jane was crazy and nobody thought to check on them? yeah, crawford and davis did the best with what they were given but the film as a whole could have learned something from roger corman, let alone  alfred hitchcock. suspense? thriller? if that's what you thought, i have beachfront property in nebraska to sell you.

Examples of Bette Davis and Joan Crawford's amazing talents.Bette Davis' Jane is both over-the-top while displaying nuances unexpected for her character. While Blanche is the heart and soul of the film.

Taut and suspenseful, Crawford and Davis mine their roles for every inch of depth they can muster.  The screenplay is much above average and the performances cannot be topped.  From beginning to end, a triumph for Crawford and Davis when the industry felt their time was over.   Throughout the film, you know there are secrets yet to be revealed, so you don't know which sister is the one you should side with.  To keep the audience in suspense for this length of time is an achievement in an age when the good guy and the bad guys are obvious.

This film is almost PERFECT. From the script, to the dialogue, to the acting. Bette Davis and Joan Crawford give 100% to their characters! This is classic that should definitely be added to your watchlist!
Two of the greatest actress of their generation, mixed with a disturbing and great story makes an amazing film that does not fail to thrill us almost 60 years later.

What a great movie.  This would have easily been 4.5* if the ending was better.  Thats the only flaw in the film.  Its very anticlimatic and uneventful.  Which is a huge surprise considering how eventful and exciting the movie had been prior to that.  This was a blueprint that Misery ended up copying.  The acting was phenomenal as you really support and feel for the protagonist while despising and hating the antagonist (who was truly villainous considering this was made a calmer time of 1962).  I loved the plot and the storyline... it progressed really well.  This was definitely a treat to watch.

A wheel-chair bound former star (Joan Crawford) is terrorised by her bitterly psychotic sister (Davis) in Robert Aldrich's edgy psychodrama, infamous for on-screen pairing of fierce rivals Davis and Crawford.  For all the furore over the competition between the two stars, it's a film which is easily dominated by (and belongs to) a phenomenally bravura performance from Davis.
Great film, but mostly due to Bette Davis and her eerie, out-of-this world performance
weird movie about an insane old lady. i enjoyed the film but i wasnt that impressed
Una historia ironica, con una gran dosis de locura y mucho ingenio. Las actuaciones protagonicas son geniales.
Ranks among the top films about jealousy.

Seriously creepy.  Bette Davis is extraordinary, and really put herself out there for this film, garish make-up and all.  She plays an aging, former childhood star who lives with her sister, played by Joan Crawford, who eclipsed her as they got older to become a star herself back in the 1930's.  Three decades later, Davis is still living in the past, craving attention, and dominating Crawford, who is in a wheelchair.  Early on, the film includes pictures and brief movie clips from Davis and Crawford when they were younger ('Ex-Lady', and 'Sadie McKee') which is nice.  I don't want to give away any of the plot, but will just say there are lots of tingly moments, and director Robert Aldrich did a great job gradually building these to a crescendo.  

The film is special because of Davis's performance, and because of its extra dimensions.  There is of course the horror of being helpless while in an unbalanced person's care, and Crawford turns in a strong performance as well.  There is also the horror of becoming irrelevant, of being deluded in holding on to a dream that has long since passed, which has a pathos to it.  The 'stories within the story' - Davis and Crawford's real-life antipathy for one another, and their own fading glory - make the movie even more fascinating.  Victor Buono is excellent as the pianist who responds to Davis's classified ad, which is her pathetic attempt to revive her act.  He's a tragic figure himself, struggling to find work and living with his nagging mother (Marjorie Bennett).  There are a few moments which strain credibility, and whether you call them plot holes or not, you may find yourself yelling instructions or warnings out to the screen (perhaps true of many a horror movie).  It's on the long side but it flies by, and never feels long.  Great movie.

This is a good film. I would imagine that Stephen King borrowed from this film to write misery, which is a film that I love and I found that the two films are very similar. Both films are about vulnerable people being terrorised by their carers. Baby Jane is dark, brooding, and menacing, and good fun, although I didn't particularly like the ending.

The most f'ed up movie I've ever seen in my life. How the hell did this get greenlit in the 60s? Also, disregard the description for this on RT or IMDb, they're both completely wrong. It's much more intense than how it's described. It's a flat-out horror movie that messed me up.
A cult camp classic.
Fantastic performances, interesting plot. Bette Davis is such a fantastic actress.
glad to have seen it after seeing the recent mini series about them both.

Eccentric, exaggerated, and creepy. This plot of this psychological thriller is so absurd and beyond obvious that it makes your skin crawl. It's predictable and so, so forced. An uncomfortable experience I'm in no hurry to repeat.

They say it is good for a romance movie if the two leads have a friendly chemistry offset. This movie may be proof that if you want a good suspense/horror movie with two antagonistic characters who can't stand each other it works to hire two actors or actresses who really can't stand each other offset.

Damn this was legit creepy and EVIL. I love the concept and the dynamic, the rabbit vs the tortoise but, yknow, with more murder. Both Bette Davis and Joan Crawford give it their all and knock it out of the park.

It verges into corny a lot, hollywood cliche crazy people kinda stuff, but keeps its integrity with how just unrelentlessly mean it is... it gets super uncomfortable to watch! But in a fun way. But also goddamn! That ending is both amazing and super unsatisfying.

10 out of 10:

Suspenseful, at times funny, and amazing performances from the two leads, Baby Jane makes for a smart, and kind of sad story.

Bette Davis is seriously diabolical as Baby Jane Hudson, a former child star who in older age shares a house with her incapacitated and much more amiable sister played by Joan Crawford. At times this early '60s thriller can be a little bit drawn out and slow to develop but when the two formidable actresses share the screen, it is great to watch.
Most famous for the backstage feud between its leading ladies, " What Ever Happened to Baby Jane?" is a twisted thriller about sibling rivalry.

While most of the second act seems to be reaching for time-filling, the first and third acts are the stronger anchors holding everything together.

Director Robert Aldrich delivers painstaking situational suspense without trying too hard, in many ways more cleverly than Alfred Hitchcock.  Instead of forcing the camera to do a lot of fancy tricks, he outright relies on suspense inherently existing within the situation the screenplay creates.  One of the best examples is when Blanche throws the note out the window pleading for help.  It's all filmed very conventionally, maddening the viewer.  First her voice can't be heard, so she writes a note, but instead of making a paper airplane, crumbles it like trash and tries tossing it.  It only reaches the edge of her own driveway, and by this point Jane has arrived home.  She thought she saw something out of the corner of her eye when she pulled in.  The note is intended for the neighbor Mrs. Bates, who remains unaware of the note.  There's no chance of her picking it up, and the only reason Jane takes the time to acknowledge her at the edge of the driveway is so she can get that note.  It's a movie, naturally we are hoping for a miracle, but it plays as it would in real life, and Jane gets the note.  Blanche is fucked.  Even more infuriating is the final scene at the beach.  Jane is a criminal on the run and she doesn't even know it, both her and her victim are sitting out in broad daylight, and she's so lost in her la la land that she's oblivious to her crimes or that the law might be after her.  And for a good while, it feels like she's going to prance around the slow stupid policeman, who are busy either eating at a snack bar or writing up information about an abandoned car, and get away with it.

I was compelled to watch this movie because I've been watching the excellent FX miniseries "Feud: Bette & Joan" which tells the story of the behind scenes relationship of the two actresses, who apparently hated each other. I originally saw "Baby Jane" when I was very young, but really couldn't remember that much about it. It's entertaining enough, but was made in a time when being subtle wasn't what being a movie star was all about, and both Davis and Crawford are very over the top as was the direction, but as it moves along it gets better and Davis had the flashy role, thus her Oscar nomination. They actually coined a saying out of this movie, "hags-ploytation", due to the unexpected success of "Baby Jane", which spawned such stellar films as "Hush, Hush Sweet Charlote" and "Straight Jacket" to name a few.
After watching Feud on FX and reading the book I was excited to see this. It was excellent,Joan Crawford and Bette Davis give great performances and create a haunting atmosphere.
I Enjoyed this movie, I thought it was well made and had a interesting Storyline. Worth watching, and a similar type of movie to  Stephen Kings Misery in my opinion.

Bette Davis is seriously diabolical as Baby Jane Hudson, a former child star who in older age shares a house with her incapacitated and much more amiable sister played by Joan Crawford. At times this early '60s thriller can be a little bit drawn out and slow to develop but when the two formidable actresses share the screen, it is great to watch.

Devastating and beautiful, Bette Davis and Joan Crawford offer up timeless performances in an unsettingly good and "way ahead of it's time" picture, What Ever Happened to Baby Jane - based on the Henry Farrell novel before it is terrifying and sweetly dark throughout. The film is only heated by the real life feud between the two actresses and the irony of their ageing attempts at making a comeback, two of the greatest actresses of all time struggling with ageism and the egocentric minds of Hollywood. The story is dark and Hitchcockian, unfolding and winding around like a tendril until it unfurls at the end and spills a cacophony of secrets onto the audience. It's not one of the scariest horror films, but it is one of the best. Bette's cackling and erratically hoarse performance as the villainous Baby Jane is timeless.
Think about it. Bette Davis is the new cinema. Joan Crawford is the silent age. This film is the most revealing expos√© of Hollywood you'll ever see.
Esse filme inventou o plot twist
marvelous performances..sadly touching
What Ever Happened To Baby Jane? (Robert Aldrich, 1962) - 9/10

can't wait to see the updated version, or even the 70's remake with Vanessa Redgrave. Crawford is formidable as always -Betty Davis, scary as hell. Baby Jane shd have died at conception. The score was horrible, as was the child star - and her singing, and her make up, and the doll.... die die die!
What Ever Happened to Baby Jane has all the right ingredients of a great cult classic movie.

Holds up well, although I would call it a "thriller", not a horror movie. DJ and I are really enjoying Feud on FX and we realized neither of us had seen the source material. If you're watching Feud and haven't seen Baby Jane I'd highly recommend it.

This 1962's classic cult film is a psychological thriller about two actresses who are sisters, one is jealous of the other's success and takes revenge by holding her paraplegic sister captive and gets increasingly mental. Starring JOAN CRAWFORD and BETTE DAVIS, perfect cast as they hated each other in real life. A great suspense story, damn ending...!
Surprising balance between traditional and unconventional cinema
That ending got me. It was great and that ending pushed it into masterpiece terrorist.

The b/w cinematography enhances the eerie and scary tone of the movie. With great acting from Bette Davis and Joan Crawford. Young Baby Jane was a child star and spoilt. The elder sister is sideline and jealous. When they grow up their roles are reversed. But Joan Crawford got into an accident and is paralyze, needing the care of sister Bette Davis. Bette is delusional and want to become famous again. She keep tormenting Joan because she hates her. Bette also forge her signature and voice to cash out money from the latter's bank. Only a helper Maidie Norman who care for Joan is her friend. Bette kill Joan pet parakeet and serve as her dinner. Joan try to throw a paper note to get help from the neighbor but it was pick up by Bette. She proceed to tell Maidie to take off day. Bette put an ad to hire a music composer and Victor Buono takes the job. Bette still perform her childhood hit song which disgust Victor but for the sake of money he endure. Maidie sneak in and know Joan is in trouble. When Bette is been force to open the door, Maidie is sad to see Joan tied and gagged. Bette use the hammer and kill Maidie. At night she dispose her corpse. The drunk Victor barge to their home to get salary. Joan manage to push the bedside table and Victor goes up to see what happen. He run out upon seeing her. Bette quickly bring Joan and escape to the beach. Joan knowing her death is coming, reveal to Bette she's the one who try to run her over but Bette evaded, cause the car crash to gate and broke her spine. Not Bette drive the car to make Joan paralyze. Bette run off to buy 2 ice creams. By then Maidie cousin has file missing person and the corpse was found. The car was also been alerted by the people and soon police found her. There's a crowd that circle Bette and she long for this attention, so she start to dance. The police quickly attend to Joan.
A post-Psycho Sunset Boulevard that amps to eleven. My how hatred can really fuel great cinematic tension.
It's a classic for a reason! That acting! That overblown score! That wheelchair! Amazing.
I don't like old movies, but I loved this one.  It's even better if you read the backstory about the rival actresses in the lead roles.

Since I am a sucker for anything with gothic undertones, I am not afraid to say that this is one of my favorite movies of all time. Joan Crawford, while a wonderful actress, is unfortunately overshined by Bette Davis, who brings an absolutely chilling performance to the table in a bright silver platter. Wink wink.

When you combine two of the greatest actresses of their time in one film you have to know it is going to be a tour-de-force of acting. Bette Davis is unhinged as Jane, but manages to maintain a logical foundation in the performance that makes it clear where this psychosis has come from. There's some serious complexity to pulling off a role where we simultaneously hate her and yet see that she isn't without any moral compass at all. Meanwhile Joan Crawford is equal parts sympathetic and scared. She also has a moment or two in the film that show depth in her character beyond those obvious traits, and that is when you can see the quality of her performance up to that point. What Ever Happened to Baby Jane utilizes a lot of techniques you typically find in horror films from that era, and it builds tension throughout. I thought there were some moments where the film got a bit far-fetched, and the level of melodrama almost strayed into the realm of comedy for me. These flaws didn't break the film, but it kept me from loving it. In many ways What Ever Happened to Baby Jane is structured similar to Misery, and I expected it would be even more intense because the lead characters were siblings. But there were enough minor things that didn't work for me that this film didn't quite rise to the level of that masterpiece. However, it is still a well-made film with a couple of legendary actresses trying to outdo one another and we get to reap the benefits of watching those performances. So I have to recommend it!
With two fantastic leads driving a well paced story, What Ever Happened to Baby Jane provides a chilling thriller that never lets up.

Sharing a distinction with Sunset Boulevard in showing the aftermath of Hollywood stardom, What Ever Happened To Baby Jane goes a step further in that we follow the fallen careers of former vaudeville child star Baby Jane (Bette Davis) and her invalid sister, the former star Blanche (Joan Crawford). How does your life go on when you had access to everything, but end up with nothing but memories and fallen glory. It is truly enough to drive a person mad.

 

The film opens with Jane being the child star on the vaudeville circuit, with all the spotlight shining on her young face and every whim of the young girl being fulfilled. At such an early age this child is being merchandised by dolls, perpetuating the idea that she is the center of the universe. Hiding in the shadows is Blanche, all but forgotten by their father who focuses on Jane's career. There is a deep resentment in her face as she watches Jane's behavior. We jump to later where Blanche is the star in Hollywood, but insists that Jane also have a film contract even though her childhood talent did not translate into adulthood. Things turn for the worse when Blanche is paralyzed in an incident that Jane is blamed for, effectively ending both of their careers. After the accident Jane has been caring for Blanche in their spacious Hollywood home. Resentment is the main ingredient in Jane's fall into madness and it finally comes to an apex when she learns that Blanche plans to sell the home for something more manageable. Resentment turns to torture, turns to terror as the film plays out.

 

Casting Bette Davis and Joan Crawford as the sisters was a work of genius. While watching the film I realized that the reason that both actresses took their respective roles was due to the intense competition between the two that had occurred for decades. Joan Crawford could make Bette Davis look terrible and Bette Davis could kick Joan Crawford around for two hours. A wonderful time was had by all. That genuine resentment between the two flows throughout the film, delivering an even deeper experience that pulls the viewer into this world that they created. Blanche is still loved and her films still run on television. Jane's vaudeville career is forgotten. Either actress could have played either role, but they were set in the roles that were best for themselves.

 

Director Robert Aldrich shoots a film that, unlike Sunset Boulevard, doesn't cast a bleak, dark world, but a world that has continued beyond the careers of the two leads. The sun still shines, people still have a good time. Aldrich follows Jane's spiral into madness, hinting around the psychological and physical torture that Blanche receives. This feeling that the world has moved on fully develops in the ending where the world around them is being entertained while the sisters are literally in the middle, gone and forgotten. An ending that seems weird, but symbolizes the entire theme of the film. No matter how famous you are, eventually the world will move on no matter what. It's a sad truth that every celebrity needs to face and some may take it better than others.

 

Films about Hollywood are always a touchy subject. The possibility of falling into the pit of over glamorizing is always an issue that can occur and dilute the message that a filmmaker is trying to achieve. With Baby Jane show business really dies in the film when Blanche is paralyzed, something that Blanche accepts, but Jane cannot do. Eventually she descends into replaying her childhood career, a middle aged woman singing songs that a young girl sang all those years ago, becoming a pathetic parody of herself. This film is a more subtle examination of the fallen star than Sunset Boulevard and stands on its own. They may be related, but they're distant cousins. Both with madness, both with terror, but this film is more optimistic. This film is one of the greats and serves as the swan song for the careers of Bette Davis and Joan Crawford. What Ever Happened To Baby Jane is a necessity in cinephile viewing.
From start to finish, an effectively directed and edited psychological drama that keeps audience fully focused on a smart and intriguing plot.
What Ever Happened to Baby Jane ? staggers a lot on the suspense, although a powerful plot twist and remarkable performances from Bette Davis and Joan Crawford grant the film a cult status.

This could be watched JUST for Bette Davis and Joan Crawford and their insane performances, but it's a really good movie besides the two stars. They certainly help, especially Davis, but the campy, dark wit and creepiness of the movie make it worth seeing as well.

Powerful story of envy, bitterness, malice and torment.

Two aging sisters, Blanche and Jane, share a large house.  Jane was once a child star and Blanche was, in adult life, a star of the silver screen.  Blanche's career ended when she was left paralysed from the waist down in an accident involving Jane.  Now Jane looks after Blanche in the house, though not very well.  Filled with bitterness at her own cinematic career never taking off, envious of Blanche's career and money, an alcoholic and a touch deranged, Jane goes out of her way to torment her sister...

A very well made thriller.  Starts off slowly and is more a relationship drama for a while.  Over time, however, director Robert Aldrich ramps up the intrigue, tension and malice.  It is soon apparent that this isn't going to be resolved simply by dialogue...

Quite Hitchcockian at times in the tension and intrigue...and menacing undercurrent.

Great twist towards the end and a powerful conclusion.

Bette Davis is superb as Jane, providing just the right level of menace and insanity.  The result is one of the scarier characters in cinematic history.  Davis got her 11th, and last, Oscar nomination for her performance.  Quite astounding that she didn't win.

Joan Crawford is solid as Blanche, and is the perfect foil for Davis/Jane.  Victor Buono puts in a good performance as Edwin and provides the movie's best comedic moments.  He got a Best Supporting Actor Oscar nomination for his efforts.
jezivost i priklju?enija

Hitchcockian psycho-thriller at times. Tour de force performance from Bette. Great settings, score, costumes, etc. 
Repercussions of a lifetime of guilt. I can't think of another movie where complex sibling relationships/rivalries are so rawly displayed.
Did't get more stars because ending/twist could have been handled better.

Mesmerising. A must for classic film buffs. Miss Davis is filled with venom and rage, clearly revelling in her chance to go at with Miss Crawford. And on Miss Crawford's end, she plays it with a wonderful amount of dignity and nobility. Rumours abound about behind the scenes fighting between the two. If so, that has only made their performances that much greater.

Takes its time rolling out the crazy, but when it comes, it screams along like a train without brakes. 
Intense, imaginative, great performances, and a thrilling story all come together to make it great.
Enjoy the ride. And what a ride!
5 glares of crazy out of 5
great old movie with lots of twists and drama.  worth a watch!

This movie is both riveting and frustrating at the same time. With good costuming, cinematography and solid performances all-round (Davis is outstanding), this is a classic drama.

inquientante y altamente extravagante. Una obra amestra

The cheap, tacky and perverse sister to Billy Wilder's masterful SUNSET BLVD. Robert Aldrich managed a truly historic feat of even getting these two iconic and open Hollywood enemies into one room much less convince them to do this movie. The making of this film is the stuff of legend. And it is important to note that at the time of its release this film was genuinely shocking to audiences who had never seen these highly respected movie stars presented in such a disturbing way. With time, this movie has become brilliantly campy entertainment. But the truly brave and brutal performance by Bette Davis is undeniably potent. Looking back, Bette Davis gave the most powerful performance of 1960. Joan Crawford's work is oddly out of place. Choosing to play it in her standard glam movie star way is without any level of realism. The mixing of not only these two incredibly charismatic actors and their widely different approaches to their craft actually serves to add a level of surrealism which is oddly effective. While most definitely a cult and campy ride of a movie, it power should never be underestimated. ...even if it was largely accidental.
Psychological thriller that snuck up on me. I've heard about it my whole like and just recently saw it. Great for its disturbing senses that created a new sub-genre called "Psycho Biddy", lol.
Surprisingly good!!!

A camp classic that never gets old regardless of the number of viewings.  Betty Davis and Joanne Crawford proved to be worthy of their billing and their real life dislike of each other just plays to the strength of the film.

The story of a little girl who grew up to become a dementedly frightful drunken ghost clown. More of a thriller, but Jane's caked white makeup and black mascara result in some of the most disturbing imagery in all of horror. A very dark and suspenseful film.

Bettie Davis throughout the whole film nails her role as the psychotic sister.

Deliriously played on center stage;  the life of two sisters who fame makes them sinister towards each other. We all know childhood fame can manufacture the most destructive celebs, Lindsey Lohan is every ones favorite example of child-star gone wrong. That's the premise to this film, Bette Davis's character was a child-superstar, with a huge fan-base her stage name was Baby Jane. It amazed me how quickly the film goes through the trivial back-story so quickly, so the film can let the main plot play out with a thriller type plot with horrific outcome. Neatly adapted screenplay from a novel I am sure is just as surprising and sinister as we watch two sister go through a story that shows close relation to Stephen King's Misery, as a envious and jealous sister who's child-star years have drifted like wreckage in the sea, takes out a built-up anger for her crippled sister, who's fame has had a more popular after-life; we watch shockingly as she pushes and torments her sister to death! Will she kill her? Will someone find out whats Baby Jane is doing. Only time will tell in this, psychotic-horror.

With a fine cast, this film needs no help, Opening quickly and to-point; although the ending could had a couple seconds longer, the movie heads into a dysfunctional and deadly relationship of two sister, ultimately leaving behind a frightening film about the essence of jealousy.
It is really a lot of funny to see two great actresses fight like this.  It is creepy, but in a good way.  Fun, popcorn movie!
all time favorite movie. classic horror
Enjoyed this psychological thriller. Wonderfully twisted and full of suspense. Bette Davis keeps you on the edge of your seat from beginning to end.

Bette Davis and Joan Crawford delivered the creepiest, grotesque performances of a lifetime dragging its audiences kicking and screaming down the murky depths of the rabbit hole and we loved them for it!

Brilliant film that evokes a sort of 1962 mash-up of Sunset Boulevard and Wait Until Dark. The acting, cinematography, and lighting is superb. I love this era in the early 60's when you had really crisp black and white films that were balanced between older and modern cinematic techniques.
This is definitely a horrorshow with a truly horrific-looking Bette Davis as the villain. No mask or monster makeup necessary.
This is a dark version of "Sunset Boulevard" with a towering performance from Bette Davis and Joan Crawford accompanied with a haunting soundtrack making the film a terrifying experience.

Suspenseful, tense, wonderfully acted and directed, What Ever Happened to Baby Jane? is a truly pleasant surprise with absolutely astonishing Bette Davis in one of her best roles and terrific atmosphere. It is at times thrilling, at times freaky, but also sometimes moving (especially the ending) look at jealousy between the sisters with superb Crawford and Davis, but particularly Davis who steals the show with her phenomenal performance. It is an entirely engaging and undeservedly underrated film, the one which is not far behind Hitchcock's best works.

What  Ever Happened To Baby Jane? is a fantastic and timeless comedic-thriller. Imagine Misery with the stylings of Alfred Hitchcock. This classic also pays homage to the golden age of Hollywood and comes highly recommended.

Dated, overlong and creepy, this film does feature two great performances and good cinematography, but the premise isn't enough to support the running time and it ultimately grows tiresome. Still, it's worth watching for the performances.
